dataSourceAttribution.summary: Expression data for the P. berghei for four stages (Rings, Young Trophozoite, Young Schizont, Mature Schizont) using Mature Trophozoite as reference.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Expression data for the P. berghei for four stages (Rings, Young Trophozoite, Young Schizont, Mature Schizont) using Mature Trophozoite as reference.

There are two datasets: HP and HPE. HP is High Producer (as in gametocytes) and HPE is High Producer "E". HP was mechanically passaged on a weekly basis from mouse to mouse and 10 independent experiments were set up (HPA-HPJ). The parasites were observed, waiting for non-producing parasites to appear. HPE was the chosen one. A deletion in HP was assumed to have created HPE (they are otherwise isogenic) and KO'd the production of gametocytes. In such a scenario the non-producer would quickly overgrow the producer. Both are cloned.

dataSourceAttribution.summary: P. falciparum Gene Ontology associations assigned by GeneDB.
dataSourceAttribution.description: P. falciparum Gene Ontology associations assigned by GeneDB.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Pfalciparum Trans-factor binding sites from Manuel Llinas
dataSourceAttribution.description:
The DNA sequence motifs bound by each ApiAP2 transcription factor were derived from protein binding microarray data using P. falciparum AP2 domains. Protein binding microarrays are non-organism specific and contain matches to all contiguous 10-mers at least once and non-palindromic 8-mers up to 32 times. The DNA motifs were determined using purified recombinant AP2 domains and the resulting position weight matrix for each AP2 domain was used to search upstream regions for significant matches. The AP2 domain that binds to each motif is indicated at the end of the gene ID. Binding sites are based on sequence matches only and have not been verified in vivo.
For further information, contact Manuel Llinás: manuel@princeton.edu

dataSourceAttribution.summary: Phylogenetic profiles based on the presence or absence of all known P. falciparum ORFs in 164 completely sequenced genomes were calculated.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Phylogenetic profiles based on the presence or absence of all known P. falciparum ORFs in 164 completely sequenced genomes were calculated. Similarity between profiles is a good indicator of functional linkages between proteins (see Pellegrini et al., 1999). Data on ORFs with the most similar profiles to a given query ORF is also available, and can be used to establish the function of uncharacterized ORFs, based on the similarity of their profiles (see Date and Marcotte, 2003) with ORFs of known function.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: P. falciparum (3D7) chromosomes sequence and annotation
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Plasmodium falciparum 3D7 genome was produced by an international consortium and should be cited using the following paper: Gardner et al., Nature 2002; 419:498-511. The completed genome, with no gaps, is being finished at the Sanger Institute and systematically re-annotated at the Sanger Institute, incorporating annotations from a community annotation workshop. A manuscript describing the latest version is in preparation.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Karolinska Institutet MTC P. falciparum Oligo Array
dataSourceAttribution.description: ArrayExpress (A-MEXP-75). The 70-mer oligonucleotides microarray consisted of 6850 probes. From there, 6542 probes (Malaria Genome Oligo Set Version 1.0) were designed and synthesized by Qiagen Operon and 14 probes were obtained from the SpotReport Alien oligo array validation system (Stratagene, CA, USA). The rest of the oligos were selected using ArrayDesigner Version 1 (Premier Biosoft International, CA, USA). Oligonucleotides were dissolved in 1:3 of DMSO:dH2O at a final concentration of 40 microM in preparation for spotting on CMT-UltraGaps slides. Microarraying was done by Genetix Qarray. Each probe was printed in quadruplicate on the slides.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Mass Spec of Female, Male and Mixed Gametocytes from the Leiden Malaria Group
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Gametocyte proteomics data from P. berghei provided by the Leiden Malaria Group. Two GFP transgenic lines (PbGFPcon, and PBGFPtub) were generated in the P. berghei ANKA strain. The sex-specific expression of GFP in the two clones was exploited to collect highly purified male or female gametocytes by Fluorescent Assisted Cell Sorting (FACS). Protein preparations were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Gametocyte proteomics data from P. berghei provided by the Leiden Malaria Group. Two GFP transgenic lines (PbGFPcon, and PBGFPtub) were generated in the P. berghei ANKA strain. The sex-specific expression of GFP in the two clones was exploited to collect highly purified male or female gametocytes by Fluorescent Assisted Cell Sorting (FACS). Protein preparations were analyzed by 1DE, LC-MS/MS.

dataSourceAttribution.summary:
RNA-Seq coverage of RBC time study from the laboratory of Henk Stunnenberg.

The raw data from this experiment can be downloaded from GEO.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
RNA-Seq coverage of RBC time study from the laboratory of Henk Stunnenberg.

The raw data from this experiment can be downloaded from GEO.

Sporozoites were purified from dissected mosquitoes fed on monkeys infected with the genome reference strain Salvador I at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, Georgia. Asexual blood stage parasites were obtained from P. vivax-infected patients in Iquitos, Peru. White blood cells were removed by CF-11 cellulose column filtration, asexual parasites were enriched by gradient centrifugation and purified by saponin lysis of RBCs. Total RNA was isolated from purified parasites and subjected to two rounds of RNA amplification for microarray analysis as described previously (Zhou, et al. 2008). Experimental technical replicate hybridizations were performed for the single sporozoite sample and two asexual samples (CM012 and CM013). Gene expression values were calculated using MOID; expression profiles were clustered using OPI as described previously (Zhou, et al. 2008).

Scott J Westenberger, Colleen M McClean, Rana Chattopadhyay, Neekesh V Dharia, Jane M Carlton, John W Barnwell, William E Collins, Stephen L Hoffman, Yingyao Zhou, Joseph M Vinetz, Elizabeth A Winzeler. Plasmodium vivax transcriptome analysis reveals divergent in vivo blood stage profiles and species-specific sporozoite gene expression. (in submission)

dataSourceAttribution.summary: The genome of Plasmodium falciparum IT was produced by the Parasite Genomics Group at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with funding from the EVIMalaR Consortium (a European Commission Funded Network of Excellence).
dataSourceAttribution.description:
The genome of Plasmodium falciparum IT was produced by the Parasite Genomics Group at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with funding from the EVIMalaR Consortium (a European Commission Funded Network of Excellence).
This draft version of the genome was generated by iterative mapping reads of P. falciparum IT against the P. falciparum 3D7 genome. Subtelomeric genes have been transferred from P. falciparum 3D7 based on location. The Parasite Genomics Group plans on publishing the completed and annotated sequence in a peer-reviewed journal as soon as possible.
Permission of the principal investigator (Matthew Berriman, mb4@sanger.ac.uk) should be obtained before publishing chromosome- or genome- scale analyses of the sequences or annotations.
Please contact Thomas Otto (tdo@sanger.ac.uk) for further details.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Late blood stage P. falciparum total proteome and phosphoproteome provided by Treeck, Sanders, et. al.
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Sample collection and mass-spectrometry were performed by Moritz Treeck and John L. Sanders of the Boothroyd and Elias labs at Stanford University, respectively. See further explanation in Treeck et. al.., 2011 Cell Host & Microbe, in press.

Synchronized P. falciparum 3D7 schizont cultures (40h +/- 8h post-infection) containing <1% gametocytes purified on a Variomacs were used for phosphopeptide enrichment and mass-spectrometry. All parasite samples were lysed in 8m urea lysis buffer, followed by trypsin digestion, strong-cation-exchange (SCX) chromatography and IMAC phosphopeptide enrichment (Villen and Gygi, 2008). Samples enriched for phosphopeptides and the flow through (containing predominantly non-phosphorylated peptides) were analyzed in duplicate via LC-MS/MS and the resulting spectra were searched against appropriate parasite protein sequence databases concatenated with reversed decoy versions of these sequences using the SEQUEST algorithm (Eng et al., 1994). Phosphorylation sites were localized using the AScore algorithm (Beausoleil et al., 2006) and the dataset was filtered using the target-decoy strategy (Elias and Gygi 2007, 2010) for peptide and phosphorylation site-FDRs <1% and a protein FDR <3%.

This bulk FDR prediction estimates that fewer than 1% of the identifications are incorrect. Given that a phosphopeptide was correctly identified, its phosphorylation sites are necessarily present, but the site's localization to a specific amino acid can be ambiguous. As a result, the Ascore algorithm was used to help localize phosphorylation sites to a specific residue. This algorithm calculates the relative likelihood that the indicated amino acid is phosphorylated versus the next-most likely residue on the peptide. An Ascore >19 indicates a >99% likelihood that the indicated phosphorylation site is correctly assigned; an Ascore >13-represents a 95% likelihood; and an Ascore >10 corresponds with a >90% likelihood. As a rule of thumb, a phosphorylation site with many spectral counts, indicating many observations, tend to be more abundant than those with fewer spectral counts. While it is true that most incorrect identifications have few spectral counts, it is not necessarily the case that phosphorylation sites with few spectral counts are incorrect.

Further scores to evaluate each individual site and peptide can be found in the supplementary data Table S1 and S2 in Treeck et. al., 2011 Cell Host & Microbe, in press.

dataSourceAttribution.summary: The genome of Plasmodium chabaudi AS was produced by the Parasite Genomics Group at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Insitute. A draft version of the genome has previously been published (PMID:15637271) but the latest version in PlasmoDB has been extensively improved by deeper sequence coverage, re-assembly, manual finishing and annotation. The Parasite Genomics Group plans on publishing these in a peer-reviewed journal as soon as possible. Permission of the principal investigator should be obtained before publishing chromosome- or genome-wide scale analyses of the sequence/open reading frames/genes on a chromosome or genome scale.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Mass Spec of Mosquito oocysts from Lasonder
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Mass Spec of Mosquito oocysts and salivary gland sporozoites by Edwin Lasonder lab.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Mass Spec of Mosquito oocysts and salivary gland sporozoites by Edwin Lasonder lab. Oocyst (OOC): 1-2 x 10^4 OOCs were collected from midguts of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 7-8 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Oocyst-derived sporozoites (ODS): 1.4-3.8 x10^7 ODSs were collected from midguts of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 13-14 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Salivary gland sporozoites (SGS): 1.3-2.5 x10^7 SGSs were collected from salivary glands of Anopheles stephensi mosquitoes (Sind-Kasur strain, 3-5 days old) 18-22 days after infection with P. falciparum gametocytes (NF54 strain). Please note that since samples were contaminated with host (mosquito) proteins, they were measured up to four times with exclusion lists to acquire MS/MS spectra of P. falciparum peptides. Sequenced peptides were excluded for sequencing in subsequent runs, resulting in an enrichment of low abundant peptides in LC-MS/MS runs.

dataSourceAttribution.summary: A high-density oligonucleotide microarray to map the position and enrichment of nucleosomes across the entire genome of P. falciparum (3D7) at three time points of the intra-erythrocytic developmental cycle using an unmodified histone H4 antibody for chromatin immunoprecipitation of nucleosome-bound DNA.
dataSourceAttribution.description: A high-density oligonucleotide microarray to map the position and enrichment of nucleosomes across the entire genome of P. falciparum (3D7) at three time points of the intra-erythrocytic developmental cycle using an unmodified histone H4 antibody for chromatin immunoprecipitation of nucleosome-bound DNA. Additionally, trophozoites were assessed with histone H3K9 acetylation (H3K9ac) antibodies. Parasites were synchronized twice with 5% sorbitol. Rings = 12 hrs; Trophozoites = 30 hrs; Schizont = 42 hrs. Raw data available in geo.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Mass Spec Analysis of P.falciparum Early Gametocytes (ISS (Silvestrini & Alano) & RUNMC (Lasonder))
dataSourceAttribution.description:
Gametocyte-free trophozoites of P. falciparum were obtained from clone F12, a 3D7A derivative which fails to produce the early gametocyte stages.
Early developing gametocytes (Early stage I-II gametocytes) were obtained using a three-step purification process of transgenic 3D7A parasites expressing a Pfg27-GFP fusion protein (expressed early in sexual differentiation).
Mature gametocytes (Late stage V gametocytes) were obtained by Percoll purification of mature gametocyte cultures previously treated with N-acetylglucosamine to clear residual asexual parasites.
Protein samples were analyzed by high mass accuracy nano-LC-MS/MS.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: P. falciparum and P. vivax proteomics data from clinical samples (Tatu)
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Data produced by proteomics analysis of clinical isolates of early stages of P. falciparum and P. vivax. Patient derived malarial parasites were directly processed and analyzed using shotgun proteomics approach using high sensitivity mass spectrometry for protein identification. Utpal Tatu, Department of Biochemistry, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560012, karnataka, India.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Data produced by proteomics analysis of clinical isolates of early stages of P. falciparum and P. vivax. contact.name: Alan Cowman
contact.institution: The Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: P. falciparum invasion pathways - array data
dataSourceAttribution.description: The malaria parasite, P. falciparum, exploits multiple ligand-receptor interactions, called invasion pathways, to invade the host erythrocyte. Strains of P. falciparum vary in their dependency on sialated red cell receptors for invasion. We show that switching from sialic acid-dependent to independent invasion is reversible and depends on parasite ligand utilisation. Expression of reticulocyte-binding like homologue 4 (PfRh4) correlates with sialic acid-independent invasion and PfRh4 is essential for switching invasion pathways. Differential activation of PfRh4 represents a novel mechanism of invasion pathway control and provides P.falciparum with exquisite adaptability in the face of erythrocyte receptor polymorphisms and host immune responses. (taken from GEO record GSE2878)
